comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: August 6(?), 1913: Before the Suffragette Caravan left New York for Boston, pulled by a balky horse that the ladies had named "Asquith," (after the British prime minister, who also proved balky on the woman suffrage question) the participants (three British Suffragettes and an American Salvation Army colonel -- with tambourine) released several Boston homing pigeons, whose flight home was supposed to herald and precede their own arrival in that city. Here is a contemporary newspaper clipping about the event: www.elizabethfreeman.org/PDF/suffrage/bostonPigeons_big.pdf New York Tribune story about "Asquith," and the non-cooperation of New York Mayor William Jay Gaynor: www.elizabethfreeman.org/PDF/suffrage/nayBoston_big.pdf

comment.author: 22242688@N00
comment._content: Goddess bless these brave women who did what needed to be done. May we always remember their hard work and persistence, and their willingness to keep on fighting the good fight.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: @Ann Arbor Deadhead: while you're at it, bless the memory of Ann Arbor's Olivia Bigelow Hall, land developer, public spirited citizen, namesake of Olivia Avenue, toiler in the vineyard of women's rights -- and a friend and supporter of Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony. Olivia Hall's papers, which include correspondence with those two illustrious women, are in the Library of Congress.
